spanishExample: ¡Deja la seguridad de tu casa y ve allá, a la guerra!
englishTranslation: Leave the safety of your home and go yonder, to the war!

spanishExample: ¡Déjame acá! Jamás te voy a dar la lista.
englishTranslation: Leave me here! I’m never going to give you the list.
vocabIncluded: déjame: leave me / let me (Dejar imperative contraction)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¡Deje el juego de mesa ahí!
englishTranslation: (Formal) Leave the board game there!
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: ¡Espera! La realidad es que sí hablas alto.
englishTranslation: Wait! The reality is that you do speak loudly.
vocabIncluded: hablas: speak, you speak (Hablar, present, 2nd person)
sí: adverb meaning "indeed" or otherwise providing positive emphasis

spanishExample: ¡Espere! Dejamos nuestras cosas medio rápido.
englishTranslation: (Formal) Wait! We’re leaving our things kind of fast.
vocabIncluded: dejamos: stop/leave/allow, we stop/leave/allow (Dejar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Esperen! Tenemos que hablar acerca de eso.
englishTranslation: (Plural) Wait! We have to talk about that.
vocabIncluded: hablar: to speak / to talk (Hablar infinitive)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¿Qué hay de tu amigo? Justo hablé con él.
englishTranslation: What about your friend? I just talked with him.
vocabIncluded: hablé: spoke, I spoke (Hablar, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Debes estar ahí para las personas.
englishTranslation: You must be there for people.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
debes: must, you must (Deber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Debías dejar eso en la Tierra.
englishTranslation: You had to(deber imperfect) leave that on Earth.
vocabIncluded: debías: had to/must have, you had to/must have (Deber, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Dejan sus cosas, pero debiste esperar.
englishTranslation: They leave their things, but you should have(deber preterite) waited.
vocabIncluded: debiste: had to/must have, you had to/must have (Deber, preterite, 2nd person)
dejan: stop/leave/allow, they stop/leave/allow (Dejar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Dejé mi lista fuera del hotel.
englishTranslation: I left my list outside the hotel.
vocabIncluded: dejé: stopped/left/allowed, I stopped/left/allowed (Dejar, preterite, 1st person)
del: "of the" before a masculine noun
fuera: out/outside (adverb often used with de)

spanishExample: Dejó sus cosas en otro lugar, no donde nosotros las dejamos.
englishTranslation: He left his things in another place, not where we left them.
vocabIncluded: dejamos: stopped/left/allowed, we __ (Dejar, preterite, 1st person plural)
dejó: stopped/left/allowed, he/she/it   stopped/left/allowed (Dejar, preterite, 3rd person)
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things

spanishExample: Ella sabía que debía hacerlo porque ahora él espera.
englishTranslation: She knew she had to(deber imperfect) do it because now he is waiting.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
debía: had to/must have, he/she/it had to/must have (Deber, imperfect, 3rd person)
espera: hope/wait/expect, he/she/it hope/wait/expect (Esperar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: En realidad, eres parte del mundo.
englishTranslation: In reality, you’re part of the world.
vocabIncluded: del: "of the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: Es el peor del equipo, pero va hacia atrás.
englishTranslation: He is the worst of the team, but he’s going backwards.
vocabIncluded: de used to single something out from a group, as in “él más grande del grupo”
del: "of the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: Esperamos que hables bajo y rápido.
englishTranslation: We hope you talk quietly and fast.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
esperamos:  hope/wait/expect, we  hope/wait/expect (Esperar, present, 1st person plural)
hables: speak, you speak (Hablar, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Esperan que dejes el juego pronto.
englishTranslation: They hope you leave the game soon.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
dejes: stop/leave/allow, you stop/leave/allow(Dejar, subjunctive, 2nd person)
esperan:  hope/wait/expect, they  hope/wait/expect (Esperar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Espero que ella sepa que solo lo hice por deber hacerlo.
englishTranslation: I hope she knows I only did it because of having(deber) to do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
espero:  hope/wait/expect, I  hope/wait/expect  (Esperar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Hay quienes dejan sus cosas fuera de su casa.
englishTranslation: There are those who leave their things outside their house.
vocabIncluded: dejan: stop/leave/allow, they stop/leave/allow (Dejar, present, 3rd person plural)
fuera: out/outside (adverb often used with de)
hay quienes: there are those who (idiom)

spanishExample: Hemos estado esperando bastante.
englishTranslation: We have been waiting quite a bit.
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No dejes tus cosas más allá de ese lugar.
englishTranslation: Don’t leave your things beyond that place.

spanishExample: No esperaba que esto fuera nada bueno.
englishTranslation: She wasn’t hoping this would be at all good.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
esperaba: hoped/waited/expected, he/she/it hoped/waited/expected (Esperar, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No has dejado nada y yo esperaba que lo hicieras.
englishTranslation: You haven’t left anything and I was hoping for you to do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
esperaba: hoped/waited/expected, I hoped/waited/expected (Esperar, imperfect, 1st person)
has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Primero dejas eso ahí y después me esperas.
englishTranslation: First you leave that there and then you wait for me.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
dejas: stop/leave/allow, you stop/leave/allow (Dejar, present, 2nd person)
esperas:  hope/wait/expect, you  hope/wait/expect (Esperar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Va a venir para acá pronto; tan pronto como pueda.
englishTranslation: She is going to come over here soon, as soon as she can.
vocabIncluded: para acá: over here/in this direction (idiom)
pueda: "be able", "he/she/it be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 3rd person)
tan pronto como: as soon as (idiom)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
